results.title: Rare Tumors Studied by MyPART - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Rare tumors can form anywhere in the body. My Pediatric and Adult Rare Tumor Network (MyPART) is studying tumors in several different body systems.

results.title: Rare Bone Tumors - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Rare bone tumors include bone cancer and cartilage cancer. They can be called by different names depending on where they are in the body. Particulare types of rare bone tumors affect children, adolescents, and young adults.

results.title: Rare Endocrine Tumors - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Rare tumors can develop in the endocrine glands and other cells that produce horomones,like thyroid, adrenal, and pituitary glands, and cells in your pancreas. There are a few specific tumors that affect children, teens, and young adults.

results.title: Rare Vascular Tumors - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Rare vascular tumors form in cells that make blood or lymph vessels, and can occur anywhere in the body, such as the skin, in the tissues below the skin, or in an organ. There are specific tumors that affect children, teens, and young adults.

results.title: Adult Central Nervous System Tumors Treatment (PDQ®)–Patient Version - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Adult central nervous system tumor treatment may include surgery, radiosurgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, surveillance, and targeted therapy. Treatment depends on the tumor type. Learn more about brain and spinal tumor treatment in this expert-reviewed summary.

results.title: Pineal Region Tumors - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Learn about pineal region tumor grades, features, causes, symptoms, who the tumors affect, how and where they form, and treatments.

results.title: Rare Tumor Clinics - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Each year, the MyPART team hosts clinics on select rare tumors at the NIH Clinical Center in Bethesda, MD. During these one to three-day meetings, people with the rare tumor and experts from around the country meet to learn more about the tumor from each other.

results.title: myPART Rare Tumor News - National Cancer Institute
results.description: The MyPART program studies Pediatric and Adult rare tumors. Read recent news about the MyPART program and other advances in the study of rare tumors.

results.title: Choroid Plexus Tumors - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Learn about choroid plexus tumor grades, features, causes, symptoms, who the tumors affect, how and where they form, and treatments.

results.title: Rare Brain and Spine Tumors - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Learn about NCI-CONNECT selected rare adult CNS tumor type grades, features, causes, symptoms, who gets which tumors, how and where they form, and treatments.

results.title: Rare Digestive System Tumors - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Rare digestive system tumors form in organs that are important for digesting food and drinks, including the esophagus, stomach, intestines, liver, and pancreas.

results.title: Inflammatory Myofibroblastic Tumor - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor, or IMT, forms in tissues called mucosal surfaces and mesentery. IMT usually starts in the lung, but it can also begin in many other places. IMTs are mostly found in children and young adults but can occur at any age. Learn more about treatment and the prognosis for IMT.

results.title: Childhood Extracranial Germ Cell Tumors Treatment (PDQ®)–Patient Version - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Childhood extracranial germ cell tumors treatment options include surgery, observation, and chemotherapy. Learn more about newly diagnosed and recurrent extracranial germ cell tumors in this expert-reviewed summary.

results.title: Rare Soft Tissue Tumors - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Rare soft tissue tumors form in the body’s soft tissues such as muscle, fat, tendons, ligaments, lymph and blood vessels, nerves or other tissue that connects and supports the body.

results.title: Childhood Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors Treatment Overview (PDQ®)–Patient Version - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Brain and spinal cord tumors may be benign (not cancer) or malignant (cancer). Both types cause signs or symptoms and need treatment. Get information about the many kinds of brain and spinal cord tumors, signs and symptoms, tests to diagnose, and treatment in this expert-reviewed summary.

results.title: Challenges for Rare Tumor Researchers - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Studying rare tumors is difficult, and MyPART is trying to address those challenges through data and biospecimen collection and sharing, clinics, and workshops.

results.title: Extragonadal Germ Cell Tumors Treatment (PDQ®)–Patient Version - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Extragonadal germ cell tumors treatment depends on the type and can include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and stem cell transplant.  Learn more about the diagnosis and treatment of extragonadal germ cell tumors in this expert-reviewed summary.

results.title: Gastrointestinal Carcinoid Tumors Treatment (Adult) (PDQ®)–Health Professional Version - National Cancer Institute
results.description: Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor treatment often includes resection of the primary tumor and local lymph nodes. Other treatment options include somatostatin analogs, interferons, treatment of hepatic masses, radionuclides, and symptomatic therapy. Get detailed information in this clinician summary.

results.title: Childhood Gastrointestinal Carcinoid Tumors Treatment (PDQ®)–Health Professional Version - National Cancer Institute
results.description: This evidence-based, expert-reviewed summary discusses the clinical presentation, outcome, and treatment of pediatric gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors, including appendiceal tumors.

results.title: Childhood Gastrointestinal Carcinoid Tumors Treatment (PDQ®)–Patient Version - National Cancer Institute
results.description: The treatment of childhood gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors includes surgery, hormone therapy, embolization, and targeted therapy. Learn more about the symptoms, tests to diagnose, prognosis and treatment of these childhood tumors in this expert-reviewed summary.
